citeinfo.title: EnviroAtlas - Inorganic phosphorus fertilizer application for 2012 by 12-digit HUC for the Conterminous United States

pubinfo.publish: U.S. EPA Office of Research & Development (ORD) - National Exposure Research Laboratory (NERL)

idinfo.useconst: None. Please check sources, scale, accuracy, currency and other available information. Please confirm that you are using the most recent copy of both data and metadata. Acknowledgement of the EPA would be appreciated.

descript.abstract:
This EnviroAtlas national map displays the application rate of inorganic phosphorus (P) fertilizer on agricultural land in the conterminous United States (excluding Hawaii and Alaska) for the year 2012 by 12-digit HUC. These data are based on International Plant Nutrition Institute (IPNI) compilations of county and state fertilizer sales for 2012 and cropland area from the USGS's U.S. conterminous wall-to-wall anthropogenic land use trends (NWALT) 2012 land cover data.
This dataset was produced by the US EPA to support research and online mapping activities related to EnviroAtlas. EnviroAtlas (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas) allows the user to interact with a web-based, easy-to-use, mapping application to view and analyze multiple ecosystem services for the contiguous United States. The dataset is available as downloadable data (https://edg.epa.gov/data/Public/ORD/EnviroAtlas) or as an EnviroAtlas map service. Additional descriptive information about each attribute in this dataset can be found in its associated EnviroAtlas Fact Sheet (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas/enviroatlas-fact-sheets).
descript.purpose:
The map, Inorganic Phosphorus Fertilizer Application, is one of four EnviroAtlas maps that display P inputs and agricultural crop P demand for the conterminous US. These data could be used either alone or in conjunction with other data layers to help identify areas where P is a significant pollutant source or where there are opportunities for more efficient management. These data could also be used in models that examine the transport and cycling of P across terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems. Information on inorganic P fertilizer application is, or will be, needed for the development of nutrient reduction strategies, nutrient credit exchanges, and payments for ecosystem services.
Because of its essential role in agriculture, but potential as a pollutant, understanding where and how much P fertilizer is applied is important to inform management strategies that increase food security and water quality across the U.S.
The overall goal of EnviroAtlas is to employ and develop the best available science to map indicators of ecosystem services production, demand, and drivers for the nation.
descript.supplinf: We distributed county-specific per-area P input rates to agricultural lands (60 m x 60 m pixels) within the corresponding county. In order to correct for some pixels with unrealistically high P application rates (most likely caused by high fertilizer sales in a county with low agricultural land), we capped P application at 6,000 kg of P per km2, which corresponds to double the highest application rate reported for corn in 2010 in the ARMS Farm Financial and Crop Production Practice survey. This alteration resulted in less than 1% reduction in total P fertilizer used compared to the reported sales data.

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Research and Development-Sustainable and Healthy Communities Research Program, EnviroAtlas

dataqual.logic: Tests for integrity have not been performed.
dataqual.complete: Features represented have not been tested for completeness

horizpa.horizpar: Data were collected using methods that have unknown accuracy (EPA National Geospatial Data Policy [NGDP] Accuracy Tier 10). For more information, please see EPA's NGDP at https://www.epa.gov/geospatial/geospatial-policies-and-standards

procstep.procdesc: Download IPNI fertilizer data at the county scale from the NuGIS website (http://nugis.ipni.net/login/)
Add the FIPS ID to the county ID numbers to avoid losing leading zeros, so the county ID can be used to match the IPNI data with the land use data.
Convert P2O5 for fertilizer to P by multiplying by 0.4364
Convert metric tons to kg by multiplying by 1000
Copy and paste these numbers to a CSV file for later use
Download NWALT 2012 land use data layer from USGS and open in ArcGIS
Overlay with U.S. county layer (make sure projection matches land use layer and reproject the county layer to Albers Equal Area NAD 1983 Albers if it does not match)
Run the zonal histogram tool to get the land use make up of each county
Copy and paste the output into Excel and transpose so that the row labels are county identifiers and the column labels are the objects (the land use IDs)

In a new Excel sheet, multiply the number in a cell (= to the number of grid cells for each land use category) by (60*0.001)^2 to get from 60m by 60m grid cell count to area in km2. Save this new sheet a CSV for later use

Using R, match the county P fertilizer CSV with the county land use CSV data using the FIPS (county identifier) and divide the total P as fertilizer by the NWALT agricultural land use area (combined cultivated crop and hay/pasture, which are coded as P43k and P44k) and save this output as a new CSV
In Excel, remove "FIPS_" from the county ID numbers with the formula =RIGHT(cell, LEN(cell)-5) to join with the land use layer.
Sort data so that the largest fertilizer application rate is at the top
Change the Inf to NAs and change NA to 0

For values of fertilizer application that are above 6000, replace them with 6000 (justification for that cut off rate: it is 2 times the average corn P application rate of farmers that were surveyed). This means that 38 counties [note that 46 counties also have NA values] have transformed P application rates. Save the Excel sheet with the updated application rates and the county identifiers for later use

In ArcGIS, used the Extract by Attributes tool to create a new raster that just has the 2 desired NWALT agricultural land uses (cultivated crops and hay/pasture) with "VALUE"=43 or "VALUE"=44 formula and save this layer
Create a binary version of that layer with the reclassify tool (1 if cell is 43 or 44 and 0 if cell is NA) and save it
Join the previously saved CSV file containing the P application rates with the U.S. county layer using the join attributes tool (base the join on the county identifiers) and export the data.
Use the polygon to raster tool to create a raster of the P fertilizer application rates from the polygons created in the previous step and using the NWALT layer's cell size of 60m.

Multiply the binary agricultural land use layer by the fertilizer application rate raster using the raster calculator tool. This distributes the county-specific annual per-area P application rate to the cultivated crop and hay/pasture lands
Used ArcGIS tool Zonal Statistics as Table to calculate mean kg/km2/yr of P fertilizer applied to each 12-digit HUC. Divided this value by 100 to convert to mean kg/ha/yr for each HUC.

cntorgp.cntorg: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Research and Development-Sustainable and Healthy Communities Research Program, EnviroAtlas

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Content Standard for Digital Geospatial Metadata

cntorgp.cntorg: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Research and Development-Sustainable and Healthy Communities Research Program, EnviroAtlas

enttyp.enttypd: Phosphorus fertilizer application in kg P per hectare per year (2012) for each 12-digit HUC

attr.attrdef: P fertilizer application is expressed as kg P per ha per year (2012). Null values indicate no data.

overview.eaover: Inorganic P fertilizer inputs in 2012 were estimated using county-level estimates of farm P fertilizer inputs. We acquired data describing total agricultural inputs (kg P yr-1) of inorganic P fertilizer to individual counties in 2012 from IPNI. We used the U.S. National wall-to-wall land use trends (NWALT) for 2012, acquired from the USGS, at the scale of 60 m x 60 m. These data were converted to per-area rates (kg P km-2 yr-1) of inorganic P fertilizer application by dividing the total P input by the land area (km2) of combined cultivated crop and hay/pasture (agricultural) lands within a county as determined from county-level summarization of the 2012 NWALT layer. The estimates were then averaged across each 12-digit HUC and converted to kg/ha/year by dividing by 100.
